title: 114_hr3560
content: The Act is titled the "Southern Utah Open OHV Areas Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act titled the "Southern Utah Open OHV Areas Act" defines key terms such as County, Federal land, Map, Non-federal land, Secretary, and State. SEC. 3. EXCHANGE OF FEDERAL LAND AND NON-FEDERAL LAND. The Secretary must accept an offer from a State to convey non-Federal land to the United States, and then convey Federal land to the State. The exchange is subject to valid existing rights and the title approval must be acceptable to both parties. Appraisals by independent appraisers determine the value of the lands to be exchanged. Appraisals of Federal and non-Federal land must be conducted by independent appraisers according to national standards. The appraisals need approval from the Secretary and the State. The State will be reimbursed for 50% of appraisal costs. The value of the land exchange must be equal. In land exchanges, if the value of Federal land exceeds non-Federal land, they must be equalized by adjusting acreage, adding State land, or a cash payment. (B) Surplus of non-federal land must be equalized in value with Federal land through acreage reduction or cash payment. Non-Federal land conveyed for off-highway vehicle use or other public purposes. The Recreation and Public Purposes Act of June 14, 1926 allows for the conveyance of non-federal land for public purposes. SEC. 4. CONVEYANCE OF LAND TO WASHINGTON COUNTY, UTAH. The Secretary will convey land managed by the Bureau of Land Management to Washington County, Utah, depicted on the map as "Hurricane Sand Dunes (NRA)", without consideration. The legal description of the land will be finalized by the Secretary, with the ability to correct minor errors. The land conveyed to Washington County, Utah, for off-highway vehicle use or other public purposes must be available for public inspection. The County is responsible for survey and administrative costs, and must agree to certain conditions for the conveyance. The County must pay administrative costs for the conveyance, release and indemnify the United States from any claims, and accept terms set by the Secretary. If the land is no longer used for public purposes, it may revert to the United States.
